I agree that a population within a =
new niche tends to grow exponentially until at some point the niche becomes=
 saturated and competition within the niche grows more intense. However, I =
don't think this hurts the argument that there may exist some optimal repli=
cator or class of replicators (say bacteria), or refutes the fact that blue=
 whales are far more inefficient replicators than bacteria. 

Even if resou=
rces were infinite and there was no density-dependent selection, it is stil=
l true that an organism that evolves to occupy a different niche will still=
 live to pass on its genes. That is, founding new niches is not directly ca=
used by densisty-dependence or escaping competition; it would still happen =
regardless as long as the new niche was a viable way of life. 

There are m=
any elements of natural evolution, and one of our challenges in EC is to di=
still the essential elements of natural evolution that lead to interesting =
open-ended complexity growth from those elements that are merely incidental=
. By doing so we can achieve a deeper understanding of why natural evolutio=
n works and perhaps bend evolution to create massively complex artifacts in=
 domains other than Earth.

So, modelling various aspects of the real world=
, such as geographic density of various organisms and resource constraints,=
 may be essential features of creative evolution, or alternatively they cou=
ld merely be incidental -- something present in nature, but not necessary f=
or creating algorithmic explosions of complexity in the spirit of natural e=
volution.  

Also, it may be possible to abstract such aspects at higher le=
vels, which also may lead to a deeper understanding; that is, we can implem=
ent some cheat that has a similar effect though it is not exactly what natu=
re did. For example, though different than the embodied geographical densit=
y-dependent selection present in nature, novelty search employs density-bas=
ed selection in an abstract space of behaviors. Of course, this particular =
abstraction may be insufficient, and other better abstractions may exist. T=
he important thing is to question the necessity or deeper meaning of the va=
rious aspects of natural evolution to obtain a concise understanding of *wh=
y* nature is able to do such amazing things.

I agree that there ar=
e many different systems that though simple in implementation or in rules h=
ave disproportionate depth. An interesting challenge is to find how to expl=
oit such systems as domains for open-ended evolution.

> 
> There was a bun=
ch of research done recently about the economies of scale and
> how that re=
lates to biological organisms, and to cities and their size and
> structure=
.  There is a definitive advantage to being a member cell of a
> multi-cell=
ular organism, just like there is an advantage to being a member
> of socie=
ty rather than having to grow your own food, make your own clothes,

Certainly a lone single-celled organism would =
not fare well in a niche requiring human-level intelligence, because such a=
 niche does benefit from multi-cellularity, having a brain, etc. However, u=
s multi-cellular organisms, by virtue of having to make multiple cells, are=
 less efficient replicators, which is the biological benchmark test. It tak=
es more time and resources to duplicate more cells. The route humans take t=
o replicate once is incredibly circuitous compared to the direct route take=
n by bacteria, but is a viable route because we do tend on average to repro=
duce at least once.

The argument is not that single-celled organisms can d=
o everything that a human can do better, just that bacteria are *quantative=
ly* better at the one measure central to evolution (and which is traditiona=
lly abstracted as a fitness function in EC): How well do you replicate (mee=
t the objective)?

Because the interesting things natural evolution discove=
rs do not necessarily score optimally high on this metric, it seems like ho=
w we abstract fitness in EC (as objectives) is much different from the role=
 fitness plays in natural evolution. While in EC we typically search for so=
mething in particular, or only look at the maximum fitness individuals, in =
nature what is most interesting is the proliferation of different ways of l=
ife, most of which are orders of magnitude less efficient when measured by =
"the fitness function" than the simplest bacteria. 

Traditional EAs conver=
ge and natural evolution diverges; the drive to diversity is such a fundame=
ntal part of natural evolution that it seems strange that our algorithms ne=
arly always have the opposite property. This dissonance suggests there may =
be something fundamentally wrong with the dominant computational abstractio=
n of natural evolution.
